This is the--what I call the second wind on the continent; the first, as former British Prime Minister Harold MacMillan said, just before the end of colonialism, that there was a new wind of change blowing across the continent and it was heralding the end of colonialism and the institution of independent states.
And, as you know, over the years, those states, newly independent, have had serious problems of governance.
I mean, many of them went the socialist route and, of course, that didn't work, Tanzania and Julius Nyerere being primary among them.

They have put in new rules of the road for African leaders and the West, in fact, in partnership.
Africans will get their economic and political houses in order, respecting human rights, respecting individual choice and civil liberties, in exchange for economic support from the West.

So I think that to posit that it's easier for countries to go from colonial systems to dictatorships is just to ignore this second wind of change that is fragile on the continent, but is nevertheless appearing, at this point, to be inexorable.
